channel.title: Big Red
channel.description: When the sun burns out, and the giant red star is formed to burn us all, where would you be and what do you think will happen to all the planets orbiting the giant red star?

item.title: Big Red
item.dc:creator: @1337h4x 1337h4x
item.description:
@1337h4x wrote:

“The gene pool could use a little chlorine.”

Read full topic

item.title: Big Red
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

Do you honestly believe the human race will last 5 billion years? Humans in our current form have only been around for 130,000 years, and you’re talking billions of years? Now with health care and social security, how is survival of the fittest going to work for the benefit of the human race? Animals thrive on natural selection, but if a poor African woman with AIDS has a many times more kids than a rich white man living in a mansion, how can we benefit from survival of the fittest? The smartest and richest have less children than average, and certainly less children than people in 3rd world countries, and therefore donate less of their successful genes to the human gene pool. As we develop more treatments to diseases, there will be nothing to remove people with defects, cancer genes, obesity genes, etc from the human gene pool. We’ll have more and more genetic defects until we all end up like those nasty prophets in 300.

Read full topic

item.title: Big Red
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

I believe the human race would have moved on alot from what it is now, and definatly would have found another planet that is inhabitable (take titan for instance).

So i don’t think it would end the human race, but where would i be? well i’d be dead ofcourse =D

Read full topic

item.title: Big Red
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

The Sun is expected to become a red giant in about five billion years. It is calculated that the Sun will become sufficiently large to engulf the current orbits of some of the solar system's inner planets, including Earth.[5][6][7] However, the gravitational pull of the Sun will have weakened by then due to its loss of mass, and all planets but Mercury will escape to a wider orbit. That said, Earth's biosphere will be destroyed as the Sun gets brighter while its hydrogen supply becomes depleted. The extra solar energy will cause the oceans to evaporate to space, causing Earth's atmosphere to become temporarily similar to that of Venus, before its atmosphere also gets driven off into space.[8] Venus will become a burnt out planet; its atmosphere having long been driven off, and its rock will melt.[1]

Read full topic
